SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD package

SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.core module

class SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.core.HypoDD(catalog, xml_path, vel_path, out_dir)[source]

Bases: object

A class to handle HypoDD earthquake relocation.

Attributes:

catalog (Catalog): ObsPy Catalog object containing earthquake events. xml_path (str): Path to the station metadata file in XML format. vel_path (str): Path to the velocity model file (CSV format). out_dir (str): Directory where output files will be stored. out_file (str): Path to the final relocated earthquake catalog. paths (str): Directory for HypoDD-related intermediate files. pha (str): Path to the phase file for HypoDD. vel_df (DataFrame): Pandas DataFrame containing velocity model information.

locate(vp_vs_ratio=1.84, out_format='QUAKEML', rm_not_locatable=True)[source]

Runs the HypoDD relocation process.

Args:

vp_vs_ratio (float, optional): The Vp/Vs ratio used in velocity modeling. Default is 1.84. out_format (str, optional): Output format for the relocated catalog (e.g., “QUAKEML”). Default is “QUAKEML”. rm_not_locatable (bool, optional): Whether to remove events that cannot be relocated. Default is True.

SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.utils.download_hypodd()[source]

HypoDD can be downloaded from https://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~felixw/hypoDD.html Helpful compiling flags: FFLAGS = -O -I${INCLDIR} -mcmodel=large

SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.utils.get_vel_layers(df)[source]

Extract velocity layers from a DataFrame with depth and vp columns.

Args:
df (pandas.DataFrame): DataFrame containing ‘depth’ and ‘vp’ columns.

  • ‘depth’: Column with depth values (e.g., in meters).

  • ‘vp’: Column with P-wave velocity values (e.g., in km/s).

Returns:

list: List of tuples, where each tuple contains (depth, vp) pairs.

SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.utils.setup_velocity_model(model_type, **kwargs)[source]

Define the velocity model for forward simulation in seismic relocation.

Modified from hypoDDpy.

The chosen model_type determines the available keyword arguments (kwargs). Supported model types include layered models with constant or variable VP/VS ratios.

Args:
model_type (str): Type of velocity model to use. Supported options:

  • layered_p_velocity_with_constant_vp_vs_ratio: Layered model with a constant VP/VS ratio.

  • layered_variable_vp_vs_ratio: Layered model with variable VP/VS ratios (IMOD 1 in HypoDD 2.1).

kwargs: Model-specific parameters, depending on model_type.

For layered_p_velocity_with_constant_vp_vs_ratio:

  • vp_vs_ratio (float): Constant VP/VS ratio applied to all layers.

  • layer_tops (list): List of tuples defining layer boundaries and velocities.

    Each tuple is (depth_of_top_of_layer, layer_velocity_km_s). Example: [(0.0, 3.77), (1.0, 4.64), (3.0, 5.34), (6.0, 5.75), (14.0, 6.0)]. Defines five layers with depths in km and velocities in km/s.

For layered_variable_vp_vs_ratio:
  • layer_tops (list): List of tuples defining layer boundaries, velocities, and ratios.

    Each tuple is (depth_of_top_of_layer, layer_velocity_km_s, layer_vp_vs_ratio). Example: [(-3.0, 3.42, 2.38), (0.5, 4.6, 1.75), (1.0, 5.42, 1.74), (1.5, 5.52, 1.75), (2.13, 5.67, 1.77)]. Defines five layers with depths in km, velocities in km/s, and VP/VS ratios.

Notes:

  • Depths are typically in kilometers, with negative values indicating above sea level.

  • Velocities are in kilometers per second (km/s).

  • The layer_tops list must be ordered by increasing depth.

See Also:

hypoddpy.hypodd_relocator: Original implementation source.

SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.utils.write_hypoDD_inp_file(vel_model, out_folder, **kwargs)[source]

Modified from from https://github.com/krischer/hypoDDpy/blob/master/hypoddpy/hypodd_relocator.py Writes the hypoDD.inp file.

SeisMonitor.monitor.locator.hypoDD.utils.write_hypoDDstation(df, out_folder)[source]

Generate station messages from a DataFrame with seismic station data.

Parameters:
df (pandas.DataFrame): DataFrame containing station information. See resp2df for details on generating this DataFrame.
Required columns:

  • network: Network code (e.g., ‘CA’).

  • station: Station code (e.g., ‘CA01A’).

  • latitude: Station latitude in degrees.

  • longitude: Station longitude in degrees.

  • elevation: Station elevation in meters.

Returns:
list: List of strings, each representing a station message.
Each message contains:

  • Station code

  • Latitude (e.g., ‘353.16N’)

  • Longitude (e.g., ‘7341.07W’)

  • Elevation (e.g., ‘436’ in meters)

Example:

'CA01A 353.16N 7341.07W 436'
